highlights.label: GOTO and other labels (e.g. `label:` in C), including heredoc labels
highlights.type: type or class definitions and annotations
highlights.type.definition: identifiers in type definitions (e.g. `typedef <type> <identifier>` in C)
highlights.attribute: attribute annotations (e.g. Python decorators, Rust lifetimes)
highlights.keyword: keywords not fitting into specific categories
highlights.keyword.coroutine: keywords related to coroutines (e.g. `go` in Go, `async/await` in Python)
highlights.keyword.function: keywords that define a function (e.g. `func` in Go, `def` in Python)
highlights.keyword.import: keywords for including or exporting modules (e.g. `import` / `from` in Python)
highlights.keyword.type: keywords describing namespaces and composite types (e.g. `struct`, `enum`)
highlights.markup.underline: underlined text (only for literal underline markup!)
highlights.markup.heading: headings, titles (including markers)
highlights.markup.heading.6: six levels ought to be enough for anybody
highlights.markup.link.label: link, reference descriptions
highlights.markup.raw: literal or verbatim text (e.g. inline code)
highlights.markup.raw.block: literal or verbatim text as a stand-alone block ; (use priority 90 for blocks with injections)
highlights.conceal: captures that are only meant to be concealed
highlights.spell: for defining regions to be spellchecked
highlights.nospell: for defining regions that should NOT be spellchecked

injections.injection.content: indicates that the captured node should have its contents re-parsed using another language
injections.injection.language: indicates that the captured node’s text may contain the name of a language that should be used to re-parse the `@injection.content`
injections.injection.filename: indicates that the captured node’s text may contain a filename; the corresponding filetype is then looked-up up via `vim.filetype.match()` and treated as the name of a language that should be used to re-parse the `@injection.content`

indents.indent.begin: Specifies that the next line should be indented.  Multiple indents on the same line get collapsed. Indent can also have `indent.immediate` set using a `#set!` directive, which permits the next line to indent even when the block intended to be indented has no content yet, improving interactive typing.
indents.indent.end: Used to specify that the indented region ends and any text subsequent to the capture should be dedented.
indents.indent.align: Specifies aligned indent blocks (like python aligned/hanging indent). Specify the delimiters with `indent.open_delimiter` and `indent.close_delimiter` metadata. For some languages, the last line of an `indent.align` block must not be the same indent as the natural next line, which can be controlled by setting `indent.avoid_last_matching_next`.
indents.indent.dedent: Specifies dedenting starting on the next line.
indents.indent.branch: Used to specify that a dedented region starts at the line including the captured nodes.
indents.indent.ignore: Specifies that indentation should be ignored for this node.
indents.indent.zero: Sets indentation for this node to zero (no indentation).

locals.local.definition.associated: the associated type of a variable

eq.description: checks for equality between two nodes, or a node and a string

any-of.description: match any of the given strings against the text corresponding to a node

contains.description: match a string against parts of the text corresponding to a node

match.description: Match a regexp against the text corresponding to a node

lua-match.description: match a Lua pattern against the text corresponding to a node

has-ancestor.description: match any of the given node types against all ancestors of a node

has-parent.description: match any of the given node types against the direct ancestor of a node

kind-eq.description: checks whether a capture corresponds to a given set of nodes

set.description: sets key/value metadata for a specific match or capture

offset.description: Takes the range of the captured node and applies an offset. This will set a new range in the form of a list like { {start_row}, {start_col}, {end_row}, {end_col} } for the captured node with `capture_id` as `metadata[capture_id].range`.

gsub.description: Transforms the content of the node using a Lua pattern. This will set a new `metadata[capture_id].text`.

trim.description: Trims whitespace from the node. Sets a new `metadata[capture_id].range`. Takes a capture ID and, optionally, four integers to customize trimming behavior (`1` meaning trim, `0` meaning don't trim). When only given a capture ID, trims blank lines (lines that contain only whitespace, or are empty) from the end of the node (for backwards compatibility). Can trim all whitespace from both sides of the node if parameters are given.
